summary:
Let \(A\) and \(B\) be sets. We define the cartesian product of \(A\) and \(B\) to be the set \(A \times B\) of all ordered pairs of elements from \(A\) and elements of \(B\). That is:

\[ A \times B = \{(a,b) : a \in A \text{ and } b \in B\} \]
title: Cartesian Product

summary:
An Abelian group is a group \(G\) whose binary operation is commutative

We remark that Abelian groups are also sometimes called commutative groups.
title: Abelian Group

summary:
Let \(A\) be a set. We call a binary operation \(\ast: A \times A \rightarrow A\) commutative if for every \(a,b \in A\):

\[ a \ast b=b \ast a \]
title: Commutative

summary:
Let \(A\) be a set. We call a binary operation \(\ast: A \times A \rightarrow A\) associative if for every \(a,b,c \in A\):

\[ (a \ast b) \ast c = a \ast (b \ast c) \]
title: Associative

summary:
Let \(A\) be a set, and \(\ast:A \times A \rightarrow A\) a binary operation on \(A\). We define an identity element of \(A\) to be an element \(e \in A\) such that:

\[ e \ast a=a \ast e=a \]

for every \(a \in A\).

We remark that when \(A\) is a group, then the identity element is unique.
title: Identity Element

summary: A binary operation on a set \(A\) is just a function \(\ast: A \times A \rightarrow A\). For any \(a,b \in A\), we write \(\ast(a,b)=a \ast b\). We also write \(\ast: (a,b) \rightarrow a \ast b\). When context is clear, we may abbreviate \(a \ast b\) as \(ab\).
title: Binary Operation

summary:
A group is a non-empty set \(G\) together with a binary operation \(\ast: G \times G \rightarrow G\) such that the following hold:

(Closure) For every \(a,b \in G\), the product \(a \ast b \in G\).

(Associativity) The binary operation \(\ast: G \times G \rightarrow G\) is associative.

(Identity) \(G\) has an identity element.

(Inverse) There exists an inverse element for every element \(a \in G\).
